title: HPI Spencer
content: The patient reports increasing pain and deformity diffusely affecting the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, with her manicurist noting that her arthritis is getting worse. She also experiences a lot of pain at the trapeziometacarpal joints. Imaging shows that the left small‑finger DIP is fused with stable hardware. She describes swelling and moderate tenderness, uses splints for pain relief but does not consider them essential, and states she is not thrilled with hand therapy and would like to consider seeing another therapist.

title: Musculoskeletal
content: On exam, bilateral upper extremities, there is a diffuse angulation and deformity at the DIP joints, moderate tenderness and dislocation diffusely to them. Unable to flex at the right small finger DIP secondary to the arthritis, but there is some remained flexion and extension of the remaining DIP joints. Moderate tenderness and dislocation at the trapeziometacarpal joint, mild shoulder sign, no tendon desquamation at the A1 pulleys. Incisions will heal. Minimal scar, some continued tenderness to palpation at the A1 pony incision. No tendon salvation at the dorsal hand. Full fist moderate soft tissue swelling, especially in the left space. Excellent range of motion overall. Some continued pain with motion.

title: Plan
content: Recommend trial of steroid injections. Talked about rebound pain, talked about temporary relief. Regarding the DIP arthritis, we discussed that there's nothing she can do to prevent worsening of the arthritis in terms of X-ray findings, but there are things that we can do to make it hurt less. That's why she's wearing the splints. She doesn't necessarily need them; they are just for pain. Recommend activity is hard. Consider DIP fusion whenever she would like. Plan will be continue therapy. Return to clinic in six weeks for follow-up.
